title: Line of purples
text:
In <a href="color%20theory">color theory</a>, the line of purples or purple boundary is the <a href="Locus%20%28mathematics%29">locus</a> on the edge of the <a href="chromaticity">chromaticity diagram</a> formed between extreme spectral <a href="red">red</a> and <a href="violet%20%28color%29">violet</a>. Except for these endpoints of the line, colors on the line are <a href="Spectral_color%23Non-spectral_colors">non-spectral</a> (no monochromatic light source can generate them). Rather, every color on the line is a unique mixture in a ratio of <a href="Colorfulness%23Saturation">fully saturated</a> red and fully saturated violet, the two spectral color endpoints of visibility on the <a href="Electromagnetic%20spectrum">spectrum</a> of pure <a href="hue">hues</a>. Colors on the line and <a href="spectral%20color">spectral color</a>s are the only ones that are fully saturated in the sense that, for any point on the line, no other possible color being a mixture of red and violet is more saturated than it.
Unlike spectral colors, which may be implemented, for example, by the nearly monochromatic <a href="light">light</a> of a <a href="laser">laser</a>, with precision much finer than <a href="MacAdam%20ellipse">human chromaticity resolution</a>, colors on the line are more difficult to depict. The sensitivity of each type of human <a href="cone%20cell">cone cell</a> to "both" spectral red and spectral violet, being at the opposite endpoints of the line and at the extremes of the visible spectrum, is very low. (See <a href="luminosity%20function">luminosity function</a>.) Therefore, common purple colors are not highly bright.
The line of purples, a theoretical boundary of chromaticity, is distinct from "<a href="purple">purple</a>s", a more general denomination of colors, which also refers to less than fully saturated colors (see <a href="shades%20of%20purple">shades of purple</a> and <a href="shades%20of%20pink">shades of pink</a> for examples) that form the interior of a <a href="triangle">triangle</a> between <a href="white%20point">white</a> and the line of purples in the <a href="CIE%20chromaticity%20diagram">CIE chromaticity diagram</a>.
In color spaces.
In <a href="three-dimensional%20space">3-dimensional</a> <a href="color%20space">color space</a>s the line, if present, becomes a <a href="surface%20%28mathematics%29">2-dimensional shape</a>. For example, in the <a href="CIE%20XYZ">CIE XYZ</a> it is a <a href="plane%20%28geometry%29">planar</a> sector bounded by black–red and black–violet rays. In systems premised on pigment colors, such as the <a href="Munsell%20color%20system">Munsell</a> and <a href="Pantone%20Matching%20System">Pantone</a> systems, boundary purples might be absent because the maximally possible <a href="lightness">lightness</a> of a pigment vanishes when its chromaticity approaches the Line, such that purple pigments near the line are indistinguishable from <a href="black">black</a>.
The <a href="RGB%20color%20model">RGB color model</a>, although "theoretically" capable of approximating the colors of the line because it is an <a href="additive%20color">additive</a> system, usually practically fails because of the limitations of the light source used. The boundary of <a href="sRGB">sRGB</a> (pictured) runs approximately parallel to the line, connecting the <a href="primary%20color">primaries</a> red and <a href="blue%20%28RGB%29">(color wheel) blue</a>, and thus purples near the line are absent from the <a href="gamut">gamut</a> of sRGB. <a href="Magenta">Magenta</a> ink, which is one of <a href="CMYK%20color%20model">CMYK</a>'s primaries, is also very distant from the line for the reason explained above. The <a href="wide-gamut%20RGB%20color%20space">wide-gamut RGB color space</a> approximates the colors on the line better, but devices capable of displaying colors with this enhanced system are prohibitively expensive for ordinary consumers.
